materials.raw_text: B: 400 g, Co: 100 g, Ge: 10 g, Sc: 40 g, Ti: 10 g

sourcing.instructions: B (Boron powder) - Chemical supply stores or online chemical suppliers; Co (Cobalt powder) - Metal supply shops or specialty online retailers; Ge (Germanium powder) - Semiconductor material suppliers; Sc (Scandium metal) - Specialty metal suppliers; Ti (Titanium powder) - Metal powder suppliers or online retailers.

1. Measure each ingredient accurately using a precision balance. 2. In a clean, dry container, add 400 g of boron powder. 3. Gradually add 100 g of cobalt powder while stirring to ensure even distribution. 4. Introduce 10 g of germanium powder, followed by 40 g of scandium metal. 5. Finally, add 10 g of titanium powder. 6. Mix the powders thoroughly using a mortar and pestle or mechanical mixer until a uniform blend is achieved.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure each ingredient accurately using a precision balance. 2. In a clean, dry container, add 400 g of boron powder. 3. Gradually add 100 g of cobalt powder while stirring to ensure even distribution. 4. Introduce 10 g of germanium powder, followed by 40 g of scandium metal. 5. Finally, add 10 g of titanium powder. 6. Mix the powders thoroughly using a mortar and pestle or mechanical mixer until a uniform blend is achieved.

steps: 1. Transfer the mixed powder into a crucible suitable for high-temperature applications. 2. Heat the crucible in a furnace at a temperature of 1200°C (2192°F) for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and alloy formation. 3. Use a controlled heating ramp to reach the desired temperature to prevent thermal shock.
heating.raw_text: 1. Transfer the mixed powder into a crucible suitable for high-temperature applications. 2. Heat the crucible in a furnace at a temperature of 1200°C (2192°F) for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and alloy formation. 3. Use a controlled heating ramp to reach the desired temperature to prevent thermal shock.

steps: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace and allow the crucible to cool naturally to room temperature, approximately 25°C (77°F). 2. This process should take about 4-6 hours; do not force cool to avoid cracking the material.
cooling.raw_text: 1. After the heating duration, turn off the furnace and allow the crucible to cool naturally to room temperature, approximately 25°C (77°F). 2. This process should take about 4-6 hours; do not force cool to avoid cracking the material.

steps: 1. After cooling, carefully remove the solidified sample from the crucible. 2. Inspect for any surface irregularities. 3. If needed, use a belt sander or diamond grinding wheel to achieve a smooth surface finish. 4. Optionally, seal the finished sample with a clear epoxy resin to protect the surface and enhance durability.
